svg.title: Geometric proof of the area of a certain triangle
svg.desc: Geometric proof of the one-seventh area triangle, based on a solution attributed (by Martin Gardner) to Hugo Steinhaus.

text.tspan: The coloured lines each join a vertex to a point one-third of the way
along the opposite edge. What proportion of the outer triangle's area
is the shaded pink region?
Use the navigation buttons at top right to see the solution.
The "Show Text" checkbox shows or hides the explanatory text.
Adding parallel lines passing through the corresponding two-thirds
points, and the vertices, gives six more triangles congruent to the
pink one, for a total of 7.
This part of the solution is reported to have been published in a
1950 book Mathematical Snapshots by Hugo Steinhaus. The explanations
and following diagrams are the work of the present author.
The parts of the six cyan triangles that project outside the original
(black) triangle are exactly congruent to the uncovered spaces. A
rotation about the centre of each line demonstrates this. The
congruences all follow from the parallelism of the coloured lines,
and the equal division of the original sides into halves and thirds.
But...
In order for this construction to be valid, we need to prove that the
additional lines we added do, in fact, pass through the vertices of
the pink triangle, for example at the circled point.
We extend the various lines of interest.
The two shaded green triangles are clearly similar, with a side ratio
of 3:1 (by construction, from the fact that line AB is divided at the
one-third point). Therefore the vertex on the left is twice the
distance A from the origin.
Likewise, the two shaded blue triangles are similar, also with a side
ratio of 3:1 (by construction). Therefore the vertex on the right is
1.5 times the distance A from the origin.
These two green triangles are clearly also similar, but this time
with an edge ratio of 7:1. Therefore the intersection with the red
line is at one-seventh of the distance to B.
And finally these two blue triangles are again similar with an edge
ratio of 7:1. Therefore the intersection with the red line is also
at one-seventh of the distance to B, same as that of the green line.
Therefore the three lines of interest intersect at a single point.
QED.

g.text: If you're seeing an otherwise blank page here, your browser doesn't support SVG animations.
